columns.text: In this exercise, we'll analyze an important characteristic of stock.

The price-to-earnings benchmark (PE) is a valuation metric that compares a company's current share price to its earnings per share. It is calculated as:

$$\text{PE} = \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Earning per share}} \tag{1}$$

Investors and analysts use PE benchmarks to measure a stock's relative value against other similar stocks. It can also be used to compare a stock to its past performance.

Generally, companies with a high PE benchmark are anticipated to grow their profits more than companies with a low PE. A low PE can imply that a stock is currently undervalued or performing extremely well compared to its historical patterns.

We are given the following information:

1. The earnings per share are $3.18
2. The benchmark PE is 18

We can use Eq.$(1)$ to find the appropriate stock price:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{PE} &= \dfrac{\text{Price}}{\text{Earning per share}} \\[15pt]
\text{Price}&= \text{PE} \times \text{Earnings per share} \\[15pt]
\text{}&= 18 \times \$3.18 \\[15pt]
&= \$57.24
\end{aligned}$$

If benchmark PE was 21, the stock price would be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&= \text{PE} \times \text{Earnings per share} \\[15pt]
\text{}&= 21 \times \$3.18 \\[15pt]
&= \$66.78
\end{aligned}$$

**Let's recap what we have done in this exercise!**

First, we explained the fundamental concept of this exercise - the PE benchmark. We have discussed its definition and where it's commonly used (and for what purpose).

Finally, we used the PE benchmark to find the appropriate stock price for the given earnings per share.
